title: At least 21 dead in torrential Dominican Republic rains
description: Torrential storms over the past 48 hours have caused flooding, damaged infrastructure and brought down houses in the Caribbean nation. President Luis Abinader said it was the 'largest rainfall event ever' in the country's history.

title: Rosalynn Carter, outspoken former first lady, dead at 96
description: The Carter Center said the former first lady died Sunday after living with dementia and suffering many months of declining health. Aides to former President Carter sometimes referred to her privately as 'co-president' because of her active role at the White House.

title: Mother of teen killed during a traffic stop in France leads a protest against police officer's release
description: A few hundred people rallied Sunday at the site where Nahel Merzouk was killed in Nanterre after the officer suspected in the fatal shooting was released from custody pending further investigation. Shouts briefly erupted when objects were thrown at police, but the gathering was overall peaceful.

title: French performers lead a silent Paris march for peace between Israelis and Palestinians
description: The crowd, which included actresses Isabelle Adjani and Emmanuelle Beart, marched on Sunday from the Arab World Institute toward the Museum of Art and History of Judaism in Paris. France, home to significant Jewish and Muslim populations, has seen weeks of protests and tensions over the Israel-Hamas war.

title: The Tamimi family's long fight for the Palestinian cause
description: Every resident of the West Bank village of Nabi Saleh is a Tamimi. Generations of this Palestinian family have protested against Israeli colonization. The most famous of them, Ahed Tamimi, was arrested and charged with 'incitement to terrorism' on November 6, just a few days after her father.

title: Medics evacuate 31 premature babies from Gaza's Al-Shifa hospital, UN says
description: Hours before the babies were evacuated, the WHO said 291 patients and 25 health workers were still inside the hospital.

title: Napoleon's hat sells for record sum at French auction
description: The hat, known as a bicorne, attracted interest from collectors 'the world over,' auctioneers Osenat said. It sold for €1.932 million.

title: Israel-Palestine: A short history of the two-state solution
description: Born of the UN partition plan for Palestine in 1947, the two-state solution represents the only prospect of a lasting settlement to the current conflict.

title: Milipol security exhibit in Paris shows sector is booming as conflicts wage on
description: The 2023 edition of the Paris-Villepinte international security equipment exhibit attracted a record number of visitors. Growing tensions across the globe are benefiting a booming sector.

title: Iranian rapper freed after year in jail for backing Mahsa Amini protests
description: Local media reported Toomaj Salehi was released on bail after publicly backing the wave of demonstrations following the death of Mahsa Amini.

title: Ukrainian teen taken from Mariupol returned home
description: Bogdan Yermokhin turned 18 on Sunday. Russia had recently issued him a draft summons to report for mandatory military conscription.

title: The first time Le Monde wrote about The Beatles
description: A new track by the Fab Four was released on November 2, more than 50 years after the band broke up, thanks to artificial intelligence. The Beatles first appeared on the pages of Le Monde on December 12, 1963.

title: Zaïre-Emery out for 'several weeks' after injury on France debut
description: The 17-year-old PSG midfielder came off injured moments after scoring in his first match for the national team, in a 14-0 win over Gibraltar.

title: Russia's new target? 'Hostile' Finland
description: The number of asylum seekers at the country's eastern border has suddenly surged. Helsinki denounced the increase as a destabilization operation by Moscow in retaliation for its NATO membership.

title: Paris 2024 Olympics: A 'hardcore' summer for transport? What message is the government sending?
description: French Transport Minister Clément Beaune warned that getting around Paris in the summer of 2024 will be very complicated. Is he telling Parisians that it would be better to stay away during the Games? Many have already decided to leave.

title: Jean Pisani-Ferry: 'The reason for the rise in long-term interest rates lies in the changes taking place in the real economy'
description: The rise in interest rates will be long-lasting and will weigh on economic policies, even if inflation falls, analyzes the economist in his column.

title: Greta Thunberg's Gaza stance splits the Fridays for Future climate movement
description: The Swedish activist, who inspired the movement, has been criticized for taking a stance deemed too pro-Palestinian.

title: Disgraced Bernard Laporte appointed director of rugby at Montpellier
description: Laporte resigned as head of the French Rugby Federation in February after he and Mohed Altrad, the billionaire owner of Montpellier, were found guilty of favoritism. Laporte's ban from holding positions in rugby is suspended during his appeal.

title: French senator suspected of drugging MP pleads 'handling error'
description: Following a complaint from MP Sandrine Josso, Senator Joël Guerriau was charged with 'administering a substance in order to commit rape or sexual assault.' He was immediately suspended from his party and parliamentary group.

title: Argentinians choose their president against a backdrop of inflation and poverty
description: The far-right Javier Milei and Economy Minister Sergio Massa face off in Sunday's second round of the presidential election.

title: The rise of the dreaded situationship: 'It's a horrible word, commitment! It sounds like the end of something'
description: A symptom of the times, more and more 20-somethings prefer to live in a gray area of love rather than declare themselves a couple

title: Ukraine gives swift justice to suspected collaborators in recently liberated areas
description: Over 7,000 criminal cases have been opened for collaboration. But there's nothing to distinguish teachers, employees or junior administrative staff from Ukrainians who have deliberately sided with Russia.

title: France's air traffic controllers refuse to accept restrictions on their right to strike
description: Air traffic controllers are protesting against a law requiring them to declare their intention to strike like other employees in the sector. France holds the record for industrial action in this domain.

title: Lives in pieces following the floods in Northern France: 'Who will buy here, now?'
description: In the space of eight days, the inhabitants of Blendecques, near Saint-Omer, have had to cope with two floods which have caused major damage.

title: Afghan cricket, champion of hearts
description: The Afghan team shone at the Cricket World Cup in India, provoking an international outpouring of support and rare jubilation in Kabul, as the country has been sinking into the abyss since the Taliban seized power.

title: How old are you really? Biological age tests become all the rage in the US
description: Longevity tests offered by a number of US startups using DNA have become popular in the United States and are slowly spreading across the globe. But how accurate are they?
